page.title: 11LOCAL HISTORY OF GRIMLEY
page.content: Grimley was mentioned in the orig- inal Domesday Book as Gremanhil and Grimanleh. Much of the land was held by the Church (re:Housing). The Domes- day Book also mentions a water mill (Ball Mill). Within living memory, the mill used to house a baker, butcher and coalman.It is now a private house. The prior of Worcester lived at the Manor in Grimley. It was destroyed at the end of the 17th century. Grimley National School was built in 1834.It is now a cottage(re:school) Derelict brickworks are by the River Severn. There was a ford nearby. Forty years ago, visitors used to swim and picnic by the river. Now fishermen are the usual visitors. The first Post Office(pre 1884) was next to the churchyard. Then it was moved next to The Manse before moving to its present site in 1936.
